problem:
I need a material for robotic structural components (8cm x 2cm sheets) that combines contradictory properties:

CURRENT SITUATION:
- Robot: Household following robot with telescopic camera stick
- Component location: Circuit/motor assembly area (high heat from motors)
- Current materials considered:
  * Aluminum: bendable for 90° angles but too heavy
  * CFRP (Carbon Fiber): very light (~60% of aluminum) but NOT bendable/formable
  * Magnesium: light but fire risk near hot motors

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Must be bendable/formable to create 90° angles without additional parts
2. Must be as light as CFRP (or close)
3. Must resist heat from motors
4. Should minimize assembly complexity (fewer screws/parts)
5. Sheet thickness around 2mm total

CONTRADICTION:
- Improving: Weight (need lighter material)
- Worsening: Formability/bendability (need to bend for angles)

CONSTRAINTS:
- Cannot use molding with CFRP (it's a rigid composite plastic)
- Magnesium too dangerous near hot motors
- Need to keep total robot weight down
- Multiple components need 90° connections

PARTIAL SOLUTION CONSIDERED:
- Aluminum sandwich: 0.5mm Al sheets + 1mm polymer foam core (cross-linked polyethylene) = 2mm total
- Uncertain if better than current CFRP solution

SUCCESS CRITERIA:
Material that is bendable, lightweight (close to CFRP density), heat resistant, and allows simple assembly with formed angles.

component_functions: Face sheets: Carry bending loads through tensile (bottom) and compressive (top) stresses, protect internal components
Core: Maintain face sheet separation distance, resist out-of-plane shear, prevent buckling, absorb impact energy
Adhesive: Transfer loads between core and face sheets via fillet geometry, maintain structural integrity at interfaces
Chassis: Support weight of motors/circuits/battery, provide mounting points at 90° angles, distribute loads
Motors: Convert electrical energy to mechanical motion, generate 150-200°C heat during operation
Circuits: Process sensor data, control motor commands, manage power distribution
Fasteners: Create removable connections for assembly/maintenance, transmit forces between components
Brackets: Form structural angles without additional parts, reinforce high-stress connection points
component_interactions: Face sheets bond to core via adhesive - epoxy cures to form fillet at cell wall interfaces creating stronger connection than just contact
Adhesive fillet geometry affects densification strain - larger fillets reduce energy absorption but strengthen bond
Core supports face sheets against buckling - must have sufficient shear strength and compression stiffness
Chassis frame connects to motors via mounting brackets - aluminum brackets flex more than steel under motor torque loads
Motors generate heat affecting nearby components - aluminum conducts heat well (237 W/mK), foam insulates (0.03-0.05 W/mK)
Circuit boards mount to chassis using standoffs/screws - must isolate from vibration and allow heat dissipation
Fasteners create stress concentrations in soft aluminum - holes can deform under high loads requiring steel reinforcement plates
Multiple components compete for limited chassis space - motors, batteries, circuits all need secure mounting within compact envelope
Bendable aluminum sheets form 90° angles eliminating separate bracket parts - but add weight compared to rigid CFRP
Adhesive bondline thickness controlled by glass beads (50-400 micron) - prevents squeeze-out and ensures consistent joint performance

step_4.evolution_path: Heavy steel (1960s) → Aluminum alloys for weight reduction (1980s) → First composites (fiberglass, wood) for better strength-to-weight (1990s) → CFRP for maximum performance but rigid (2000s) → Sandwich structures for optimized stiffness-to-weight but thick (2010s) → Current challenge: Need formable lightweight materials combining best of aluminum (bendability) and CFRP (lightness)
past_problems: Weight vs Strength trade-off: Heavy materials strong but inefficient, light materials often too weak
Formability vs Performance: Metals bendable but heavy, composites light but rigid after curing
Cost vs Performance: Advanced materials (CFRP, titanium) excellent but prohibitively expensive for mass market
Assembly complexity: Multiple parts needed for angles - bolts/fasteners add weight and cost
Corrosion and degradation: Steel rusts, aluminum corrodes, plastics become brittle, affecting longevity
Material compatibility: Galvanic corrosion between dissimilar metals (Al + CFRP), adhesive failures
Manufacturing limitations: Cannot easily form composites post-cure, limited to molded shapes
Thermal management: Metals conduct heat well (motors), composites insulate, sandwich structures mismatch expansion
lessons_learned: Lightweighting critical for robotics: Every gram saved improves efficiency, speed, battery life, and reduces motor load
Formability enables design simplification: Bendable materials reduce part count (one bent sheet vs multiple flat sheets + brackets)
Material selection must match operating environment: Indoor household robots different from industrial or outdoor robots
Adhesive bonding is weakest link in sandwich structures: Interface failure mode dominates, fillet geometry critical
One-size-fits-all materials don't exist: Trade-offs between weight, strength, formability, cost, manufacturability
Minimum thickness constraints matter: Sandwich structures need 8mm+ to perform, incompatible with thin compact designs
Heat resistance essential near motors: Aluminum excellent thermal conductor (237 W/mK), foam poor (0.03 W/mK)
Economic viability crucial: CFRP performs excellently but cost prevents mass market household robot adoption
Anisotropy of composites requires careful design: Fiber orientation determines strength direction
Simple joining methods preferred: Welding/soldering better than bolts for weight and assembly speed, but not all materials support this

current_achievement.status: CFRP achieves 60% of Al weight (1.6 vs 2.7 g/cc) but sacrifices formability. Partial success.
Aluminum formable but heavy. CFRP/sandwich rigid. Formable CFRP emerging but expensive. Major gap.
Both Al (10-40k psi) and CFRP (higher) provide adequate strength. Well solved.

cost_magnitude.details: CFRP $20-50/kg very expensive. Aluminum $3-5/kg moderate. Foam cores $2-10/kg variable. Adhesives $15-30/kg. Sandwich total material cost 3-5x higher than single aluminum sheet.
CFRP requires autoclave curing (expensive equipment, 4-8h cycle). Aluminum bending fast (minutes) but requires press brake. Sandwich bonding needs curing time (1-24h depending on adhesive type).
Multi-part bolted assemblies need screws ($0.10-0.50 each), drilling, alignment. Labor $20-40/hr. Bent single-piece designs eliminate 50-70% fasteners and assembly time.
CFRP: Autoclave $100k-1M, layup molds $5-50k. Aluminum: Press brake $15-100k, bending dies $500-5k. Sandwich: Heated press $30-150k. High capital investment.
Every 1kg robot weight increases motor power 20-30%. Aluminum 2.7 g/cc vs CFRP 1.6 g/cc means 40% more battery drain over lifetime. Energy cost compounds over 5-10 year life.
Multi-material designs require FEA analysis, interface design, thermal expansion matching. Engineering time 2-4 weeks for sandwich vs 1 week for simple aluminum. $80-120/hr engineering cost.
CFRP prepreg has shelf life (6-12 months frozen), trimming waste 15-25%. Aluminum scrap recyclable but 10-15% waste. Adhesive once mixed has pot life 30min-2h, unused portion wasted.
Sandwich structures need NDT inspection (ultrasonic) for adhesive voids $200-500/panel. CFRP requires fiber orientation checks. Aluminum simpler visual + dimensional inspection $50-100.
Corrosion treatment for aluminum (anodizing) adds $5-15/part. CFRP impact damage difficult to repair - often full part replacement. Sandwich delamination failures require re-bonding or replacement.

harm_severity.impact: CFRP cannot be bent after curing - eliminates ability to create 90° angles in single part. Forces multi-part bolted assemblies with 2-4x more parts, fasteners, assembly time, weight, and cost. This is THE core contradiction.
harm_severity.source: Material properties research, design constraints from CFRP rigidity

harm_severity.impact: Steel rusts (loses integrity), aluminum corrodes in wet/acidic environments, plastics become brittle in UV/cold. Reduces 10-year expected lifespan to 3-5 years. Anodizing adds $5-15/part cost.

harm_severity.impact: Multi-material sandwich structures (Al + foam + adhesive) cannot be easily separated for recycling. 100,000 tons electronics discarded daily, <10% recycled. Environmental and regulatory pressure increasing.
Aluminum CTE ~23 ppm/°C, foam ~50-80 ppm/°C, CFRP ~1-2 ppm/°C. Temperature cycling 20-80°C causes differential expansion leading to delamination, cracking, loss of structural integrity.
harm_severity.source: Sandwich structures thermal analysis, failure mode studies

harm_severity.impact: Core-facesheet interface is weakest part of sandwich. Delamination is most common damage mode. Epoxy fillet geometry critical - errors cause 20-50% strength loss. Re-bonding complex and expensive.
harm_severity.source: Sandwich panel failure analysis, structural testing data

harm_severity.impact: CFRP $20-50/kg, autoclave $100k-1M, engineering time 3-4x aluminum. Final robot cost $800-2000 vs target $100-500. Prevents mass adoption - only 30% market penetration vs potential 70%.
harm_severity.source: Market research, price sensitivity analysis, adoption barriers

harm_severity.impact: CFRP voids (3-10% volume), fiber misalignment (±5°), adhesive bondline inconsistency reduce strength 15-40%. NDT inspection required adds $200-500/part. 5-15% scrap rate typical.
harm_severity.source: Quality control data, manufacturing defect statistics

harm_severity.impact: Magnesium lightest metal (1.8 g/cc) but ignites at 473°C. Motors reach 150-200°C. Fire hazard near heat sources eliminates this otherwise ideal lightweight option. Safety regulations prohibit use.

ideality_calculation.benefits_calculation: Lightweight(10*6=60) + Formable(10*5=50) + Strength(9*8=72) + Heat(9*7=63) + CostEffective(8*4=32) + Assembly(8*5=40) + Durability(7*6=42) + Manufacturing(7*7=49) + Compact(6*3=18) = 426 total weighted benefits, normalized = 5.76 avg
ideality_calculation.costs_calculation: Material(8) + Manufacturing(7) + Assembly(6) + Equipment(9) + WeightPenalty(7) + Design(5) + Waste(4) + QC(6) + Maintenance(5) = 57 total cost magnitude, normalized = 6.33 avg
ideality_calculation.harms_calculation: ExcessWeight(9) + NonFormable(10) + Corrosion(7) + EWaste(6) + ThermalMismatch(7) + AdhesiveFailure(8) + HighCost(8) + Defects(6) + FireRisk(9) = 70 total harm severity, normalized = 7.78 avg

step_9.ideality_category: POOR - System is problematic and far from ideal. Score <0.5 indicates costs+harms exceed delivered benefits. Urgent improvement needed.
key_insights: CRITICAL GAP: Non-formable CFRP (harm severity 10) combined with lightweight need (importance 10, achievement 6) creates the core contradiction. Cannot have both lightness AND formability with current materials.
MAJOR COST DRIVER: Equipment costs (magnitude 9) for CFRP autoclave and sandwich processing are prohibitive for mass market. This multiplies through to final product cost harm (severity 8).

WEIGHT-PERFORMANCE TRAP: Aluminum formable (achievement 5) but heavy (achievement 6 on lightweight). CFRP light (would be achievement 9) but rigid (achievement 0 on formability). Stuck between poor options.
HIDDEN HARM: Excessive weight (severity 9) cascades - reduces mobility, drains battery 20-30% per kg, shortens lifespan, increases motor wear. Single harm amplifies across system.

BENEFIT UNDERACHIEVEMENT: Top 2 importance items (lightweight 10, formable 10) have lowest achievement (6, 5). System optimized for wrong priorities - strength (9,8) well-solved but not the bottleneck.
COST-HARM AMPLIFICATION: High material costs (magnitude 8) directly create market accessibility harm (severity 8). Same issue counted twice in denominator, crushing Ideality.

IDEALITY IMPROVEMENT PATH: If formability improved to 8 (bendable CFRP) and weight to 8 (near-CFRP density), new Benefits = 7.26. If this eliminates multi-part assembly (costs -2) and thermal issues (harms -2), new Ideality = 7.26/10.11 = 0.718 - still poor but 76% better!
TARGET: Ideal system would have Ideality >2.0 (benefits 2x costs+harms). Current 0.408 means need 5x improvement. Focus: Solve the formability-weight contradiction.

BENCHMARK CONTEXT: Traditional aluminum-only robots ~0.6 Ideality (formable but heavy). Pure CFRP concept ~0.35 (light but rigid + expensive). Current sandwich attempt 0.408 - marginally better than extremes but still problematic.

component_functions: Face sheets: Carry bending loads through tensile (bottom) and compressive (top) stresses, protect internal components
Core: Maintain face sheet separation distance, resist out-of-plane shear, prevent buckling, absorb impact energy
Adhesive: Transfer loads between core and face sheets via fillet geometry, maintain structural integrity at interfaces
Chassis: Support weight of motors/circuits/battery, provide mounting points at 90° angles, distribute loads
Motors: Convert electrical energy to mechanical motion, generate 150-200°C heat during operation
Circuits: Process sensor data, control motor commands, manage power distribution
Fasteners: Create removable connections for assembly/maintenance, transmit forces between components
Brackets: Form structural angles without additional parts, reinforce high-stress connection points
component_interactions: Face sheets bond to core via adhesive - epoxy cures to form fillet at cell wall interfaces creating stronger connection than just contact
Adhesive fillet geometry affects densification strain - larger fillets reduce energy absorption but strengthen bond
Core supports face sheets against buckling - must have sufficient shear strength and compression stiffness
Chassis frame connects to motors via mounting brackets - aluminum brackets flex more than steel under motor torque loads
Motors generate heat affecting nearby components - aluminum conducts heat well (237 W/mK), foam insulates (0.03-0.05 W/mK)
Circuit boards mount to chassis using standoffs/screws - must isolate from vibration and allow heat dissipation
Fasteners create stress concentrations in soft aluminum - holes can deform under high loads requiring steel reinforcement plates
Multiple components compete for limited chassis space - motors, batteries, circuits all need secure mounting within compact envelope
Bendable aluminum sheets form 90° angles eliminating separate bracket parts - but add weight compared to rigid CFRP
Adhesive bondline thickness controlled by glass beads (50-400 micron) - prevents squeeze-out and ensures consistent joint performance

steps.title: Analyze Past evolution

past_systems.system: Heavy steel structures (cast iron, structural steel)
problems: Excessive weight (density 7.8 g/cc) limited mobility and speed
High energy consumption for movement
Difficult machining and fabrication
Rust and corrosion in harsh environments
Overkill strength for most non-heavy-duty applications

past_systems.system: Aluminum alloys (pure Al with Cu/Mg/Si additives)
problems: Still relatively heavy (2.7 g/cc - only 1/3 lighter than steel)
Lower strength compared to steel (1/3 the strength)
Corrosion in wet/acidic environments
Cannot be joined by soldering - only fasteners or special welding
Galling and tool sticking during machining
Hole deformation under high stress loads

past_systems.system: Fiberglass (glass fiber + polymer resin), Wood composites
problems: Moderate strength, heavier than advanced composites
Brittle failure modes - catastrophic fracture
Limited temperature resistance (plastics degrade in sunlight/cold)
Moisture absorption in wood leads to warping
Not formable after curing - fixed shape only
Lower specific strength/stiffness than carbon fiber
Very expensive material and processing costs
NOT formable/bendable - rigid after curing
Cannot be molded into complex 3D shapes easily
Anisotropic properties - weak in certain directions
Galvanic corrosion when paired with aluminum
Complex manufacturing - autoclave curing required
Difficult to repair - cannot weld or easily patch

past_systems.system: Aluminum foam sandwich (Al face sheets + foam core)
problems: Minimum thickness 8mm to unleash potential - thicker than traditional sheets (0.5-2mm)
Adhesive bonding critical - interface failure common weak point
Core density variations cause performance inconsistency
Cannot easily reconfigure or reshape after assembly
Still heavier than pure CFRP solutions
Thermal expansion mismatch between layers
Limited formability - cannot bend sandwich after bonding

findings.evolution_path: Heavy steel (1960s) → Aluminum alloys for weight reduction (1980s) → First composites (fiberglass, wood) for better strength-to-weight (1990s) → CFRP for maximum performance but rigid (2000s) → Sandwich structures for optimized stiffness-to-weight but thick (2010s) → Current challenge: Need formable lightweight materials combining best of aluminum (bendability) and CFRP (lightness)
past_problems: Weight vs Strength trade-off: Heavy materials strong but inefficient, light materials often too weak
Formability vs Performance: Metals bendable but heavy, composites light but rigid after curing
Cost vs Performance: Advanced materials (CFRP, titanium) excellent but prohibitively expensive for mass market
Assembly complexity: Multiple parts needed for angles - bolts/fasteners add weight and cost
Corrosion and degradation: Steel rusts, aluminum corrodes, plastics become brittle, affecting longevity
Material compatibility: Galvanic corrosion between dissimilar metals (Al + CFRP), adhesive failures
Manufacturing limitations: Cannot easily form composites post-cure, limited to molded shapes
Thermal management: Metals conduct heat well (motors), composites insulate, sandwich structures mismatch expansion
lessons_learned: Lightweighting critical for robotics: Every gram saved improves efficiency, speed, battery life, and reduces motor load
Formability enables design simplification: Bendable materials reduce part count (one bent sheet vs multiple flat sheets + brackets)
Material selection must match operating environment: Indoor household robots different from industrial or outdoor robots
Adhesive bonding is weakest link in sandwich structures: Interface failure mode dominates, fillet geometry critical
One-size-fits-all materials don't exist: Trade-offs between weight, strength, formability, cost, manufacturability
Minimum thickness constraints matter: Sandwich structures need 8mm+ to perform, incompatible with thin compact designs
Heat resistance essential near motors: Aluminum excellent thermal conductor (237 W/mK), foam poor (0.03 W/mK)
Economic viability crucial: CFRP performs excellently but cost prevents mass market household robot adoption
Anisotropy of composites requires careful design: Fiber orientation determines strength direction
Simple joining methods preferred: Welding/soldering better than bolts for weight and assembly speed, but not all materials support this

steps.title: Identify all current Costs

cost_magnitude.details: CFRP $20-50/kg very expensive. Aluminum $3-5/kg moderate. Foam cores $2-10/kg variable. Adhesives $15-30/kg. Sandwich total material cost 3-5x higher than single aluminum sheet.
CFRP requires autoclave curing (expensive equipment, 4-8h cycle). Aluminum bending fast (minutes) but requires press brake. Sandwich bonding needs curing time (1-24h depending on adhesive type).
Multi-part bolted assemblies need screws ($0.10-0.50 each), drilling, alignment. Labor $20-40/hr. Bent single-piece designs eliminate 50-70% fasteners and assembly time.
CFRP: Autoclave $100k-1M, layup molds $5-50k. Aluminum: Press brake $15-100k, bending dies $500-5k. Sandwich: Heated press $30-150k. High capital investment.
Every 1kg robot weight increases motor power 20-30%. Aluminum 2.7 g/cc vs CFRP 1.6 g/cc means 40% more battery drain over lifetime. Energy cost compounds over 5-10 year life.
Multi-material designs require FEA analysis, interface design, thermal expansion matching. Engineering time 2-4 weeks for sandwich vs 1 week for simple aluminum. $80-120/hr engineering cost.
CFRP prepreg has shelf life (6-12 months frozen), trimming waste 15-25%. Aluminum scrap recyclable but 10-15% waste. Adhesive once mixed has pot life 30min-2h, unused portion wasted.
Sandwich structures need NDT inspection (ultrasonic) for adhesive voids $200-500/panel. CFRP requires fiber orientation checks. Aluminum simpler visual + dimensional inspection $50-100.
Corrosion treatment for aluminum (anodizing) adds $5-15/part. CFRP impact damage difficult to repair - often full part replacement. Sandwich delamination failures require re-bonding or replacement.

steps.title: Calculate current Ideality score

ideality_calculation.benefits_calculation: Lightweight(10*6=60) + Formable(10*5=50) + Strength(9*8=72) + Heat(9*7=63) + CostEffective(8*4=32) + Assembly(8*5=40) + Durability(7*6=42) + Manufacturing(7*7=49) + Compact(6*3=18) = 426 total weighted benefits, normalized = 5.76 avg
ideality_calculation.costs_calculation: Material(8) + Manufacturing(7) + Assembly(6) + Equipment(9) + WeightPenalty(7) + Design(5) + Waste(4) + QC(6) + Maintenance(5) = 57 total cost magnitude, normalized = 6.33 avg
ideality_calculation.harms_calculation: ExcessWeight(9) + NonFormable(10) + Corrosion(7) + EWaste(6) + ThermalMismatch(7) + AdhesiveFailure(8) + HighCost(8) + Defects(6) + FireRisk(9) = 70 total harm severity, normalized = 7.78 avg

findings.ideality_category: POOR - System is problematic and far from ideal. Score <0.5 indicates costs+harms exceed delivered benefits. Urgent improvement needed.
key_insights: CRITICAL GAP: Non-formable CFRP (harm severity 10) combined with lightweight need (importance 10, achievement 6) creates the core contradiction. Cannot have both lightness AND formability with current materials.
MAJOR COST DRIVER: Equipment costs (magnitude 9) for CFRP autoclave and sandwich processing are prohibitive for mass market. This multiplies through to final product cost harm (severity 8).

WEIGHT-PERFORMANCE TRAP: Aluminum formable (achievement 5) but heavy (achievement 6 on lightweight). CFRP light (would be achievement 9) but rigid (achievement 0 on formability). Stuck between poor options.
HIDDEN HARM: Excessive weight (severity 9) cascades - reduces mobility, drains battery 20-30% per kg, shortens lifespan, increases motor wear. Single harm amplifies across system.

BENEFIT UNDERACHIEVEMENT: Top 2 importance items (lightweight 10, formable 10) have lowest achievement (6, 5). System optimized for wrong priorities - strength (9,8) well-solved but not the bottleneck.
COST-HARM AMPLIFICATION: High material costs (magnitude 8) directly create market accessibility harm (severity 8). Same issue counted twice in denominator, crushing Ideality.

IDEALITY IMPROVEMENT PATH: If formability improved to 8 (bendable CFRP) and weight to 8 (near-CFRP density), new Benefits = 7.26. If this eliminates multi-part assembly (costs -2) and thermal issues (harms -2), new Ideality = 7.26/10.11 = 0.718 - still poor but 76% better!
TARGET: Ideal system would have Ideality >2.0 (benefits 2x costs+harms). Current 0.408 means need 5x improvement. Focus: Solve the formability-weight contradiction.

BENCHMARK CONTEXT: Traditional aluminum-only robots ~0.6 Ideality (formable but heavy). Pure CFRP concept ~0.35 (light but rigid + expensive). Current sandwich attempt 0.408 - marginally better than extremes but still problematic.
